thread.title: Judge grants Dianna Duran more time to ready defense
thread.title_full: Judge grants Dianna Duran more time to ready defense | Albuquerque Journal News

author: Dan Boyd / Capitol Bureau Chief
title: Judge grants Dianna Duran more time to ready defense
text:
District Judge Glenn Ellington has granted a request by embattled Secretary of State Dianna Duran for more time to prepare her defense in a high-profile case in which Duran is accused of using campaign contributions to cover personal spending at casinos.
In a motions hearing today in Santa Fe, Duran’s attorney argued she needs more time to review more than 20,000 pages of case-related documents provided by the Attorney General’s Office — many of them bank records — and to prepare additional motions.
“The defense has a right to challenge the evidence, and we need to have the time to do that,” Erlinda Johnson, Duran’s attorney, said in open court.
The judge granted the request, but did not provide the full 60-day extension sought by Duran. Instead, a preliminary hearing in the case that had been set to begin Oct. 30 is now scheduled to start Dec. 1.
AG’s office attorneys argued against the motion today, saying Duran had not shown sufficient cause for an extension to be granted.
In all, Duran is charged with 65 violations by the Attorney General’s office. Although the amounts allegedly withdrawn at eight casinos run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars, the counts against her revolve around 19 transactions totaling about $13,000.
In brief remarks after today’s hearing, Duran’s attorney claimed the Republican secretary of state has already been “convicted by the media” but looks forward to fighting the charges against her. Duran was present for today’s hearing, but did not speak to reporters.
Check tomorrow’s Journal for a full story.
